* Toronto stocks were expected to continue to climb at the

Trading should be thin ahead of the U.S. holiday weekend.
Toronto stocks were expected to continue to climb at the open on Friday and analysts said the index could break through the record session high of 6348.02 reached March 11.

"We closed at the session high and at a record closing level, that's bullish... so we're looking for a positive day today, break above 6348, and we'll see how high we go," said MMS International technical analyst Katherine Beattie.
She said the market will be boosted by a seasonal bias as U.S. players secure investments ahead of the U.S. Memorial Day holiday weekend, which will also lighten session volumes.
"Volume is going to be light because a lot of U.S. participants are already on holiday," Beattie said.
The U.S. bond market will close early at 1400 EDT/1900 GMT ahead of the holiday.
Beattie said gold remains a market negative but bullish sentiment elsewhere should offset the sector's weakness.
"Gold is under pressure, (prices are) down over a dollar, and that's going to be a weakness that's going to weigh on the gold sector, but it shouldn't be a heavy weight on the TSE 300," Beattie said.
The Toronto Stock Exchange's key 300 composite index rose 22.89 points on Thursday to close at 6336.02, erasing the last record closing high of 6332.87 set on March 10.

Bankruptcies in Canada rose to 8,147 in March from 7,775 a year earlier, the Department of Consumer and Corporate Affairs said on Friday. Statistics Canada said Canadian operating profits in the first quarter of 1997 increased 3.3 percent to a record C$25.5 billion.
